thread.title: National Park officials prepare for Appalachian Trail
thread.title_full: National Park officials prepare for Appalachian Trail

title: National Park officials prepare for Appalachian Trail
text:
Great Smoky Mountains officials expect increase in traffic when Appalachian Trail movie debuts 
THE ASSOCIATED PRESS Published: 8/22/15 3:41 pm EDT - Updated: 8/22/15 3:43 pm EDT 
MARYVILLE, Tennessee â€” National Park officials are expecting a spike in traffic along the Appalachian Trail after the release next month of a Hollywood film about two hikers who attempt to conquer the 2,190-mile route. 
The Daily Times in Maryville ( http://bit.ly/1PHfqlo ) reports Great Smoky Mountains National Park officials saw a 60 percent increase in traffic in the area after the book, "A Walk in the Woods: Rediscovering America on The Appalachian Trail," was published. The movie is based on the 1998 book and stars Robert Redford and Nick Nolte . 
Christine Hoyer, backcountry management specialist for the park, says officials knew the movie was coming. She says the land managers with responsibility for The Appalachian Trail have been working with The Appalachian Trail Conservancy to deal with the expected increase in traffic. 
Information from: The Daily Times, http://www.thedailytimes.com
